cards.from: YE HERALD OF FERELDEN | DENIM’S ONLY ROYALLY AUTHORIZED BROADSHEET | ACCEPT NO UNWORTHY IMITATIONS | SECOND NOVEMBER EDITION
cards.content: VISCOUNTESS ISLAY CHARTERIS PUT UNDER HOUSE ARREST! DEMANDS TRIAL! ARRESTED UNDER ORDERS OF KNIGHT-COMMANDER TRAHAN OF THE TEMPLAR ORDER Wise readers will be aware of the name of Viscountess Islay Charteris, one of the most socially influential women in Ferelden. She is perhaps best known as the originator of the current trend of elaborate pictorial embroidery in women’s dress in Denim's nobility. It was noted in the last edition of this broadsheet that Viscountess Charteris was missed at a ball held recently at which her attendance was scheduled, entirely uncharacteristic behavior on the part of the good Lady. This broadsheet is the first news source of any note to learn the source of this unexpected absence, in this exclusive report from Ferelden’s Herald. Per the public records and announcements of the Ferelden Order of Knights Templar, Viscountess Islay Charteris was placed under house arrest on the orders of Knight Commander Trahan of the Templar Order, charged with the willful obstruction of and interference with Templar business. Viscountess Charteris, from her home in Denim, has protested this punishment of house arrest and has demanded a legal trial. Her husband, the Viscount Charteris, who invariably follows his wife’s wishes, has personally seen Knight-Commander Trahan to ensure that his wife has a fair trial. Viscountess Charteris laments being absent from the many functions on her social calendar, as well as only being able to send letters by pigeon, lest the Templars posted at her door read her correspondence without returning them. What she calls the “deepest blow” in this exclusive report to the Herald is the fact that guests cannot come to her home without being searched before they leave, much to her distress, as her number of callers has greatly decreased. Knight Commander L. Lowen Trahan helms the honorable Order of the Knights Templar in Ferelden, headquartered in Denim. Our wise readers will be familiar with our Knight Commander, who, despite being one of the youngest Knight Commanders in Ferelden history, has slain three abominations. The Knight Commander reports that Viscountess Charteris was “treating Templar affairs as if they are cheap gossip” and “needed to be taught that her jawing has consequences before [Viscountess Charteris] gets someone killed.” Her authority, she says, comes from the authority of the Chantry over the Maker’s people. This revelation comes at the close of an eventful period for the Templars, who have been unusually busy within the city of Denim. Our wise readers will recall the Knight Commander’s beheading of an apostate found and held by Templar novitiates in September, increasing Templar surveillance due to the continued danger of an apostate presence in the city. Some believe that this situation may be related to the dangerous abomination originating from the Alienage, which was mercifully dispatched by our own Knight Commander. Regular readers will recall our previous articles regarding these events, which were covered more thoroughly at the time. All the more reason to subscribe to the Herald of Ferelden - Denim’s only royally authorized broadsheet.

Goodness, it must be a busy time for your order in this little kingdom of ours? The things I’ve been hearing sound so terribly dangerous and exciting. Secret conclaves of mages, wandering apostates in cities, rogue heretics in the countryside, abominations, ooh, you must be so brave! I know you haven’t been able to write much recently because you’ve been so terribly busy, don’t think that Lady Rohesia doesn’t tell me these things! As soon as you’re not doing important Templar things I expect a fulllllll letter and one to your faithful Essie too! You’re still planning a summer wedding, yes? And I’m still in pride of place on the invite list, surely? I jest, I jest, I know all about it from your lovely lady. 
I know you’ve been kept away from the center of the world - Denim, you know, where everything happens! Oh my goodness, you might not have even heard yet, on the other side of Ferelden. Oh, my, do I get to be the first to tell you? It isn’t that I take any pleasure in it, but it’s such important information that I feel rather important getting to tell it. You know, I had noticed that our poor Knight Commander was looking a little haggard - I suggested myself that she should get some well deserved rest! She just looked so tired and worn and like she was taking on work that wasn’t hers, you know? Oh, I simply felt awful when I heard that she’d suffered a heart spell and wouldn’t be on her regular duties. The Maker gives his strongest battles to his stoutest shields, they say! I’m sure we’ll all miss her ever so much until her return. Do you think that will do anything to your work, dearest? I just love hearing your thoughts on our honored Knight Commander.

I know, darling, I know what you were thinking before this letter reached you. "Oh, I just received a letter from sweet Islay, surely it will be some time before she has something else so interesting that she must write to me!" Well, my friend, these are interesting times we live in, if nothing else, and oh, do I have something to share with you! I'm sure you've heard (from me, no less!) the rumors swirling regarding a certain Commander of a certain specialized force that operates in a grey area, if you understand. Regarding her fitness, her age, if that age has made her judgment doubtful, her health, so on and so forth. And I only have another thing to add to this! That grey commander was seen not only fraternizing with a criminal in Denim, but actually picking them up and taking them with her! Is that who the grey wardens they have to fill their ranks with now? Common, dangerous criminals from the streets of Denim taken in front of all and sundry? Can we really trust that judgment? Would you, my dear?

As always, it was a delight to have you and Ivor over for dinner! It’s been so trying, having my society so limited, so you can imagine how splendid it is to get back to business as usual. I forgot to mention this little tidbit to you over dinner - you had ever so much to tell me about Orlais, and you know, I told you about my ordeal in Templar custody! It slipped my mind, and all the better, since I’ve gleaned a little more information off dear Arwyn. He knows everyone who isn’t anyone, you know, and I handle proper society for him. I wish I knew more particulars, honestly, but half information is better than no information, as you know!
Alas, no names. A certain Denim noble has been ill for some time, and apparently, it’s the sort of thing that can’t be handled with poultices and the apothecary. Too serious to be cured by anything besides magic. Usually, you just ask for aid from the kingdom’s Circle, but apparently the Ferelden Circle didn’t have anyone they could send! Apparently it’s, like, a whole thing, darling, and it’s been inconveniencing the family of this suffering noble terribly. They had to send to Orlais for someone who’s actually able to perform the kind of magic you use for illnesses, with an escort and all. I feel terribly sorry for whoever it might be, really - having to wait so long to be cured without knowing why! It tugs the heart strings, it does. You don’t have any idea who it might be, do you? I mean, between friends, of course.
P.S. I do have to specify, since I was the one to tell you of the poor Knight Commander’s heart spell, that this has nothing to do with her unfortunate health troubles. I hear that she’s the type of Templar who won’t be healed by a mage, anyway. More importantly, darling - did you see she was out for the first time after her unfortunate spell and she’d cut her hair? Ugh, it’s so short, it looks terrible! Andraste didn’t make us women just to throw that away and look like the weaker sex!

cards.content:
Islay, my love, I know it’s only been months since we last saw each other, but it feels like it’s been years. Ivor and I are on the long journey back from Orlais - by boat, this time, you know it’s what Ivor prefers. It’s been lovely, actually, it’s sort of a travel ship especially for nobles chartered by the Queen - though I suppose that’s neither here nor there. It’s a lovely courtesy for the Queen to extend us, but she’s always been very nice to her Ferelden friends. I know ages ago she sent some manner of gift - masks? - to the late lamented Keepers. I still can’t believe that, really, it seems I was exchanging letters with Dorothea yesterday. And the King! One of the Queen’s ladies-in-waiting gave us flowers personally as condolences for King Gornemant - Ivor was acquainted with him, of course, and it was a touching gesture. She said something about the Queen hoping her Ferelden friends would remember her kindly, as she remembered the Keepers and the King. The Orlesians are truly only second to Ferelden in terms of hospitality and thoughtfulness. Though it helps that my Ivor is such a charming gallant.
This is to say, of course, that I hope your schedule is free in a fortnight when I return. I’ll host at mine, and I’ll reserve your day from teatime til the evening after dinner. You know my table settings are unmatched, and my menus are tied only with yours in terms of taste. How I long for that pleasant evening of conversation, just the four of us, unworried and discussing the most important affairs of the season. With Orlesian wine, naturally; it would be unimaginable to take a trip and not bring back any.

I know your duties are an honor and a service to the Maker. I cannot help resenting how they take you away from me. We are planning our nuptials, and I cannot arrange to have you posted any closer than Jader? That glorified trading post? It makes my blood boil! As if there is not enough talk in this city about apostates hiding in plain sight. It isn’t all people can talk about, but because I am wedding a Templar - capitol T - they feel the need to tell me their personal fears. As if I can do anything about elven alienage apostates or abominations or secret mage maids. If they even exist! I see why you complain about it, I do. It’s even sillier when it’s me. What am I going to do, pick your sword up and start swinging it around in the marketplace when I see someone acting suspiciously magical?
Wretched. Wretched! And I am left with your silhouette on a cameo and your scarf to wrap around myself and pretend it’s you. What can possibly be so important in Jader that it needs to keep me from you? Our wedding is coming up and I don’t have you here to plan it with me! I don’t see how your commander thinks this is an acceptable situation, but she’s hardly available for critiques. And I don’t want you getting in trouble because I decided to poke my nose into things. I say this with love - you know this, my beloved - but you really are glorified security. Can’t they just have you wander around Denim looking important, or something? Jader! I suffer so and it isn’t even my fault.

Darling, there’s irony in calling Jader a glorified trading port when I am truly from a glorified trading port. I can imagine you saying it, too, which just makes me miss you. If we were already wed, you could come with me to Jader and stay in the residences the Chantry keeps for templar wives. I did try to make an argument for you, being our wedding is close, and it isn’t like there would be impropriety. I mean, you’d be quartered with a bevy of other wives, any impropriety is your own business. You know, I’ve been at this for a while now, and once you have tenure you start thinking you can get away with wiggling the rules a little. And this is so minor, you would think, hm? Apparently letting an unmarried fiancee stay in the wives’ quarters is how you start the downfall of the Templar Order.
I could say that there are other things that will lead to the downfall of the order, but I’m a nice man, so I won’t. There are finer things to talk to my bonny bride about. Frankly, I have no idea why I am in Jader. The others gossip - not me, no, I’ll just repeat what I hear. Though I don’t listen much. Important mage prisoners, or something in the seedy underbelly? The first is our bread and butter, so I imagine it’s right, though it isn’t really gossip. Apostates seem to be a silver a dozen now, between there and Denim. Hey, maybe if you try again and tell the commander how terribly scared you are without your big strapping templar to protect you from apostates? Don’t you think it’s worth a try?
Ever your knight in shining armor ;)

cards.content:
May the Maker preserve His Templars, and grace our late brother Knight Commander Kindelan with a place at His side. Selection time for the vacancy left by him will be soon. I am the longest serving Knight Seneschal in Ferelden, and we know the way our Order works. I write to give you my particulars to give to the blessed Divine for her review. I, Jago Trahan, fifty nine, have served as Knight Seneschal of the Enys Isles for thirty years, since the death of my father, Lowen Trahan. I have not been disciplined for insubordination, because I am not a churl or a coward. My records are available to you, but I have put down two abominations with my own sword. There are no reasons why I would be an unfit Knight Commander.
Above all: it would be my honor and sacred duty to serve Ferelden as Knight Commander. My sword and shield would serve the Maker and His Templars before all else. My girl should become Knight Seneschal of the Isles in my place, if you'll allow it. Don't worry about her whelping a litter, she is a Templar before she is anything else. She will not shirk her duties, as I did not shirk mine with her. I await your reply at my post on the Isles. May the Maker keep you well.

cards.content:
DAUPHIN STILL IN MOURNING Bereft Dauphin Swears He Will Never Love Again

VAL BAYEUX - Jean-Antoine, Dauphin de Orlais, again declared his intention to never wed at a soiree held at the Vicomte de Clerembault's salon earlier this week. The Dauphin, citing the death of 'the woman closest to his heart,' said he 'could never give his love so freely again.' Pressing his silk handkerchief to his face, his voice wavered as he spoke of his deceased beloved. The young noble the Dauphin corresponded with with aims to marriage was killed along with her House in a raid by the Ferelden Order of the Knights Templar several months past. No arrangements were finalized, but the Dauphin has said they were coming to an engagement. The Dauphin was seen at the salon in deepest mourning attire; black brocade surcoat with black silk tunic, polished black leather boots, and a fine Antivan black lace jabot. Holding the jabot is a locket of Ferelden jet carved in the form of a heart - which the prince showed at the salon. In the interior are excerpts from letters; his paramour's signature, and the Dauphin's name written by her. The Dauphin kissed the locket with a sigh prior to repinning his jabot. When asked by the Vicomte if he was 'making a hasty decision about never marrying, as a future king' the Dauphin gasped and pressed his hand to his mouth in offense. Declaring that 'he knew as soon as he heard she was dead that he'd lost half of his heart' and that 'he could never endure that again,' the Vicomte was forced to apologize to the Dauphin. Her Highness, The Reine of Orlais, had put forward no comment on her son's deep mourning as of publication time.

cards.content: One knife. One caravan. Seven hearts. Seven throats. Caravan of seven fledgling greys, traveling the remote road. Catch them unawares, in the night, and leave their bodies for the crows. You have one chance. {The ink impression of a feather pressed against the page is the only sign off at the bottom of this letter.}

I had forgotten how difficult it is to ensure letters reach people who are constantly traveling, an ironic thing to forget given how often I was in your position. This isn't an excuse for the tardiness of this letter, mind, but perhaps reflects the general state of confusion that the city and I both have been in. My duties have been pulling me in one direction, then another, and I have finally found something to pull me towards the writing desk. My personal letters have all been gathering dust, I regret, with Orlais, the Wardens, and our mutual friend the Templar. Maker save us from politics.
I am beginning with the subject you do not like to broach, as there is no avoiding it now. I will keep it brief. Under the current circumstances, you must seriously consider what it would mean to take it, and what that would entail for you. If you finish this consideration and decide that you will, know that I would aid you. Please consider this with the same gravity I do. I thank you, Estell. Now to what I do not wish to discuss: I need you to trust me, and my actions. There are pieces in motion I cannot explain now, but will be clear later; I do nothing without reason. One day I will explain, but for now, I ask you to trust me. Let us move to more pleasant subjects.
 I know your last letter was some time ago, but I would feel wrong to go without replying to it. It makes me proud to see the knight you have become in spite of the training you disliked. If dislike is a strong enough word, hm? I regret that I wasn't able to have you join and train in my own company of knights, rather than the order. The training you are receiving now, however, is going to be more valuable to you than that would have been. What's most important for a good knight is to learn what it means to travel the roads, to meet people, to see what you can do for those people, to try to do good. You're only starting to come into your own, Estell. Even if you don't, you've come far.
Most of my business does not bear mention; I am incredibly busy, so much of it frivolous. I hope that one of my duties will allow me to visit Kanevedenn in time for Tenenan's birthday; to make sure the flowers are ready. I doubt our paths will cross in person soon, but I hope that you will write when you are able - I understand that you are as busy as I am, if not more. While I can hold myself to standards of tardiness, it would be absurd to do that to a young knight on the road. I'm not sure if I sent a letter in a timely fashion until I was far too old to have a good excuse. You, however, have a very good excuse, and don't have an old soldier's bad habits. I hope you are well, Estell, and I look forward to your reply.

I have about a dozen sheets of scrap paper next to me that I'll have to burn after this, but it feels like there's no good way to write this letter.
I don't know if you heard I've finally graduated from Templar-Recruit. It seems that this was only the beginning of my luck, because I have been deemed fit to receive "a special education" from Knight-Commander Trahan herself. 
Sir, I think if I fail this she will kill me.
That is actually not the point of my letter. My first lesson was Commander Trahan trying to convince me the Templar Order's Way was the only way to stay alive. She shared a story of when she was a girl and her father brought her on her first abomination hunt. She shared that even before she was 10 she was well trained enough to use her shield and distract the abomination that used to be her friend well enough for her father to kill it. She then went on about the importance of knowing how to use my shield, constance vigilance, and that she was <u>lucky</u> to be trained so well at such a young age or else "that <u>thing</u> that pretended to be [her] friend" would have "torn [her] throat open and cracked [her] skull to get at the meat."
Sir. What <u>was</u> that? What am I supposed to do about that?

Oh how are you, darling? Is darling Ivor well, and please tell me he’s going to be called back from whatever diplomatic tomfoolery he has to do in Orlais soon? Denim is positively dead without you, darling! And what would you do without me to tell you what’s been happening on the social scene? You would be so woefully out of date. It’s just dreadful that the biggest social event of the season was for something so terribly tragic. Oh, our poor dead King! It feels like he was cut down in the height of his prime, doesn’t it? Oh, I know he was in his fifties but it was all so sudden and public that it makes it feel positively tragic, like something in one of the plays they put on in Denim! I must tell you about it - of course I was in attendance, everyone who is anyone in Denim was in attendance in their best and most funereal. It was so terribly sad, darling, like any proper funeral should be. 
Really, darling Lilias, my heart bleeds for poor Conn - the Lord Commander lets me call him Conn, you know. The King’s death has affected him so terribly and he was already in such a state! He read the most touching eulogy about the King, his dearest friend and closest companion - did you know he saved the King’s life during the war when he lost that arm? I had no idea, darling! They were inseparable! When he started weeping you know I can never stop myself from weeping too. Oh, poor Conn! After, you know, the funeral things, was what everyone was looking forward to - the feast. And oh, Lili, the poor man was blind drunk when the feast was barely started - he came up to talk to me, you know, and I felt terribly for him. He showed me the ring the king gave him, you know (and what a ring, Lilias, the prettiest pale blue sapphires and gold you’ve ever seen)! He was saying something tragic about this being the last time he could kiss Tristram’s ring, and how unfair it was that he had to bury his best friend when he loved him so much, when one of those other knight types came and took his arm. Conn was put out, but the knight was so apologetic and I told him nonsense, he had nothing to apologize for but loving his best friend! Well, that made the poor man sob and by then my love was back from dreary conversation and we had our meals to worry about, you know. Oh, Lilias, isn’t it just tragic? And you missing all of it in stuffy old Orlais is doubly tragic! Write soon, darling, and come sooner.
cards.meta: Lilias Spens, Lady Islay, Gossip, Connomor, Rumours, Gossip

cards.content:
You know me, but discretion requires the artifice of disguise, both of my handwriting and my name. The topic of this missive is a sensitive one, and I urge you, read no further unless you are in private or amongst loyal friends. Our mutual secrets must remain as such, honored Arlessa.
With solitude assured, I know of the trouble you're having, my Arlessa. I have seen this before, though do not let that statement provoke as much fear as it may have previously. This mother's nightmare is one that has happened before, to noble ladies like you, of the most august rank. I also know your hope - that this might be somehow resolved without the loss of your son and heir, and without the looming shadow that bears not mentioning. The purpose of this letter is hope, honored Arlessa, and a solution. The man who bears this letter is a mage who has spent time in noble households, training scions or siblings in the careful art of mastery and concealment. There is no con, I offer his services to you, with the only charge being ensuring his living needs and concealment. Don't let this recommendation surprise you - again, you know me, honored Arlessa. I wish nothing but health and happiness for you and the young lordling.
cards.meta: Shou Tucker, Arlessa Carina, Tristram Gornemant III, Arl Pelham

cards.content:
Ah, you have a way of making the most tempting invitations. What a truly delightful soiree you have planned for your anniversary! The guest list, it is impeccable. I would add my name, and the name of my son to it, but I am too busy with him and the Arl to be able to come. Mon ange has a new tutor, and oh, I practically must attend the lessons to be able to keep up. Such an intelligent man, so thorough, and yet still young and handsome - it quite strikes one. I had not known that you could get such good tutors here, but I am to be surprised yet. 
And you know how boys may be at that age, all focus and ready one moment, out the window woolgathering at the next. I tell you, ma chére, I positively have my hands full here with this boy and his lessons and ah, all the things he needs to be Arl! They do not teach you this, you know? Or warn you, truly, that motherhood is the most exciting job a noble woman will have. Oh, to be young and carefree once more, no worries and no tutors, and free to go to any ball I please. Not that I would trade chèr Tristram for anything in the world, never, nothing could induce me to. But ah, we had some fun, you and I, before les hommes came around. I miss those days, chérie. We should write more, don't you think? It is nice to hear of Orlais, and the perfume of your paper smells like home. 
Je vous envoie mes amicales pensées,
cards.meta: Arlessa Carina, Tristram Gornemant III, Shou Tucker, Arl Pelham, Orlais, La Dame

cards.content:
Let the seal you broke marks how seriously I take the confidentiality of this letter and any correspondence between us. This matter is extremely delicate, and I am trying to avoid a wider panic within or without my own household. Please do not mention this to anyone outside your order until the situation is taken care of - both for my sake, and for the sake of others. My castellan hired a series of new servants over several months, to fill positions vacated due to death or marriage. One of these maids claimed to be an Orlesian girl from the borderlands named Rosine, with the expected references for a girl of her status seeking her position. I vet my castellan's hires - the habit of a meddling old commander, I’ll admit, but one I find indispensable - and found no issues with the girl.
There was no trouble until one of the other serving girls came terrified to our Templar garrison, reporting what she'd seen the Orlesian doing. She was an apostate mage practicing baneful spells, Knight-Commander, placed within my household. If Tenenan was alive, an Orlesian girl with her skills would have been made one of her ladies' maids. Perhaps she escaped from the Circle, I had heard a rumor to that effect, but I keep thinking of her Orlesian accent. I would like to play it off as the paranoia of an old veteran, but -  an Orlesian mage is a strange thing in Ferelden, and I know you will agree with me. Please give me some peace of mind, Commander - examine other recent hires to noble households, make sure no one else is in danger. Write as soon as you can.
Beneath my seal,
cards.meta: Connomor Katell, Commander Trahan, Tenenan, Orlais, Rosine

cards.content:
I've had this sent by courier across the city so you won't have to come back for the list and be delayed. Tip the girl, for me, if you please. What we need for the preparations are as follows, and accept no substitutes:
  • 10 warriors under different, but well-respected patrons, to bear the king's sarcophagus to the tomb.
  • One wrought iron brazier for each Aeducan king to rule Dwarvezammar to illuminate the palace for his lying-in-stone.
  • 5 jars of my namesake from Bitumen's distillery.
  • 1 pound of mica dust.
  • Funerary robes, fully beaded (must include amethyst & onyx & the most common stone types) and embroidered with gold and silver thread.
  • Funerary crown from the royal treasury (stone).
  • The Heir's funeral raiment from the royal treasury. Do not pick the wrong raiment; each is stored and labeled with the name of each one of the king's children and grandchildren. The other heir's raiment shouldn't be an issue, since she wore it to her funeral.
  • An update from the assistant stonecarver on the progress for the plinth. Your stone effigy is almost the spitting image of King Aeducan, and you aren't even done.
  • A meal for yourself, for the sake of the stone.
The good thing about royal funerals, bedrock of my heart, is that there is a formula for them. This one was thrown off somewhat by the preceding one, but the formula is the same. Yes, there are many steps and preparations involved, but this is our job. Worrying yourself sick over the preparations won't make a good funeral; trusting yourself will. There's no finer stonecarver and planner to give our king the ceremony he deserves.
cards.meta: Dwarveszammar, bedrock, Fifi, King Aeducan, Funeral

cards.content:
My good man, I hope this letter gets to you in a time of respite. Grand Cleric Nevenou and myself regret that we’ve been unable to offer more personal condolences in the wake of the King’s death. The funeral feast and solemn requiem as said by the Cleric were lovely, a fitting testament to a King, but ah, ah, as impersonal as most fanfare and ceremonies are. Save for your eulogy.  At a funeral for a King, a head of state, you seemed one of the few to be grieving Tristram, the man behind the title. It’s this kind of thing that reminds you why the Maker made our world: a simple show of love and devotion between His creations. Which is why I must write this letter, you see, as I worry no one else has written one sincerely. A worrier, my parents always called me, but I like to say that I'm just particular about people, details, that kind of thing. And I worry at the idea that everyone was so busy memorializing The King, The Figure, to remember the best friend he left behind.
You don’t need a Chantry Mother to tell you you have a heavy burden on your shoulders; I wonder sometimes if our habit of stating the obvious is part of what drives people away - though that’s neither here nor there. What I want to extend is my personal condolences, Lord Commander, to you. With them, a little sachet of herbs from the Chantry gardens - my people were alchemists and herbalists in Jader, you know, the Jaffrezes? I think they’re well grown and mixed, for a relaxing tisane but please, judge for yourself - I’m getting off track again, ah, ah. These past months must have been tremendously difficult, and it’s a testament to the man you are that you’ve kept both composure and sobriety. The Maker will see your strength and devotion to your late King and Kingdom, and reward your fidelity. But beyond our Maker, it’s important to know that people see that, and I guess this is what this letter is about, really. Knowing that you’re not going it alone; we have the eyes of our Maker and the thoughts of others with us. Either way - I hope I can be someone you can write to in times like these, or perhaps chat - my diocese is not far from yours in Denim, aha.

What has come over you in your absence?
You are not acting like yourself, and I fail to see a reason for this. After all, a reason would imply a benefit to yourself or your plans, whatever they may be. Such is how I raised thee. Yet there is no benefit plain before my eyes when I look on from afar. The people with you are of no consequence, yet. Yes, yes, I will admit that anyone can become significant given enough time, and even I do not always spy the future. But, really, my child - Wardens, and none of them with more than a few years’ service? What can guising your character from them do for you? Gain you the approval of a motley party of no account?  You play at pleasing them and garnering their attention as if it has any material benefit. It is as baffling to watch as it is irritating to my sensibilities.
There comes a point I must ask: do you plan on becoming some kind of mystic adviser to these, frankly, third rate Wardens? What else could you expect to gain from this otherwise? Your reward, I suppose, being a position conditional on the approval of others, a marginal connection to true power. Really, now. To be constantly putting up a meek facade to please cheap conjurers and journeyman adventurers, knowing your place might be lost because of their inconsequential disapproval. You know as well as I do that that is not what you want, and more than that - what a miserable fate for someone so talented! Even more so, what a diabolical waste of the magic I weaned you on.
This is beneath your dignity as my child and as someone with magic in your very blood. Your power comes from within, not from being a sycophant to inconsequential pieces on a wider board. I do not speak lightly when I say you need not prove yourself to others. Your magic and your wits are within you, not in the amusement and approval of others. Draw from that. Act like who you are: my son, and someone who magic is strong in. That will never betray you.

cards.from: <character onclick='charDetails(`Lady Rohesia Roskelley`)'>Lady Rohesia Roskelley, Arling of the High Coast</character>
cards.content: You have no right to talk to me that way. I am the fullborn daughter of the Arlessa of the High Coast. My ancestresses have been ruling over your home since the good Maker raised it from the sea. You will show me the respect due to me regardless of my minority. I wrote you one letter prior to this, my good commander, and if you consider one letter wasting time - well, it reflects on the Order, not on my conduct. It is not espionage to wish to know where my betrothed will be stationed and why he will be stationed there! I wrote to you as a courtesy, in deference to your role as his commander and respect for your position. What did this respect for Templar authority earn me? A threat that my beloved will be “reprimanded” for my “wasting Templar time.” Would that I skipped that ordeal and just wrote to my love - but he does not know why he is stationed in Jader, either! We are not commonly in the business of sending ships to ports without informing the hands of cargo or destination. I am not questioning the Maker’s shields, my good commander - but a Lady must inquire. And inquire I will. No Templars have been stationed at the Circle for some time, it seems - even the new Orlesian reinforcements invited into the kingdom, which are chiefly in Denim. Those that are stationed at the Circle remain guarding the docks. Interesting. In turn, a significant detachment of Ferelden Templars have gone to Jader to be posted to the Templar building there. But they do not know why - as my love shows. There must be a reason, yes? Something which needs Templar attention? And for some reason, the Templars attending to this need to be Fereldan, as my betrothed? The Orlesian Templars go straight to Denim, passing Jader. It is interesting! I am aware of your reaction to criticisms from Lady Charteris. I invite you to dance if you want to, commander. Under my mother's seal,

cards.from: <character onclick='charDetails(`Trahan`)'>Knight Commander Trahan, of the Templar Order, Denim</character>
cards.content:
I understand why you chose to meddle in Templar affairs. Nosy wench. I should have known all along. Your paltry excuses of wedding plans never held water. If you write trying to interfere again, I will have your accomplice court martialed for his role in this. I know you are friends with that little witch and her whore of a mother. You see where their iniquity has led them. Your willingness to write openly shows you share their lack of shame. You should pray to Our Maker for forgiveness for your disobedience to His Will. His Mercy is the only mercy you and that beldam apostate should expect to receive. When I finally put her and her mother to the sword, I will make sure you are watching.
No Templars will be re-stationed. Their posts are set for a reason and it is not the will of man that sets them. If your accomplice was a man even worthy of marriage he would want to remain at his post and do his duty to Our Maker. I will make sure he learns what being a Templar means. Do not write to him. You should respect this order and your Maker enough to avoid meddling in Holy affairs again.
cards.meta: Essie, Rohesia, Kim Keeper, Dorothea Keeper, Trahan, Templars

cards.content:
I know a lady’s education is a change of pace for you, darling, but you will adjust to the circumstances. You miss your mama, your bedroom, and the comforts of home - but I can already tell you’re making friends with the other young people just from your letter. Soon you’ll be having too much fun and learning too much to rush off to your room in the evening and write your mama about every little thing. It sounds like you are doing splendidly, you’re just a little restless. I remember being your age, darling, and worrying about impressing a score of other lords and ladies - well, they are worrying the same thing, so it’s all very silly. You see, your worries are natural, we have all had them.
Which means, no, you cannot come home yet, darling. You only just started. A letter from home should make you feel better - I know I felt like the west was the middle of nowhere, but the best education is found on the old estates, you know. Society hasn’t been very active, but I can answer one of your questions. I know you were quite fond of the Marquise Latreille’s protege - you admired her, at least, and I think a girl that smart is a splendid one to admire. Why, she herself is abroad from Orlais polishing her skills right now - answering your question as to how she was. I’ll let the Marquise know you asked after her. Think, by the time you’re done with your schooling, she might be back from Antiva or wherever she is, and won’t you be very impressive then? All the more reason to stay at your studies, darling. Mama will mail you your favorite coverlet and maybe a flacon of your favorite scent from la rue des parfumeurs. Doesn’t that make things sound easier?
Visiting soon,

cards.title: La Sur-Arbre Overview
cards.content:
The religious order that maintains political control of La Sur-Arbre (The Church of Ascension) is an active participant in the threat to our existence. Due to La Sur-Arbre's location (floating in static orbit around our chunk and passing over the city of New Limnsworth on an approximately daily basis), we are uniquely situated to deal with this threat; of the threat groups identified, we can most directly deal with them utilising our own agents.

Background:

Prior to the Fault, a country known as the United Settlements of Aarakocra (USA) was geographically north of Limnus (the country to which the city New Limnsworth then belonged). Sharing a landmass and being in close proximity, the USA frequently invaded Limnus, typically over resources (specifically, the coveting of Limnus' plentiful oil fields). While these invasions were typically rebuffed by the standing Limnian military, due to the relatively low efficacy of the USA military, attempts to counter-attack and claim USA territory were universally unsuccessful due to the terrifying power of the Warrior Cats, the USA's largely Tabaxi defensive forces.
Following the events of the Fault, the capital of the USA was split apart from the majority of the countryside over which it had held dominion. The resultant lack of access to key agrarian land led to an attempted popular uprising; the Church of Ascension, relatively small at this point in the nation's history, saw this as an opportunity to establish a hold on political capital and backed the uprising, powerful divine magic being used to provide necessary food and equipment. The resultant civil war was ended with the defection of the Warrior Cats to the Church and the ceding of the then-democratic government to the Church; the USA was dissolved, and the chunk was named La Sur-Arbre.
Through the continued fealty of the Warrior Cats and effective chokehold on essentials on the chunk (the Church continuing to produce the majority of basic supplies and foodstuffs), the Church has seen very little domestic resistance, and is simultaneously beloved and despised by the ordinary citizenry of the chunk. While some attempts have been made by other chunks to capture the city-state, all such efforts have been rebuffed by the continuing merciless power of the Warrior Cats; in addition, their position (in orbit above our chunk) provides them with an unparalleled position from which to wage extremely destructive war on New Limnsworth.

Involved Parties and Groups:
  • The Church of Ascension
  • The Anatre Possenti
  • Warrior Cats
  • His Holiness Pope Salvarentus VI
Suggested Approach:

Given the extremely lethal nature of the defensive forces on this chunk, all-out assault with no advance preparation should be avoided at all cost. If a confrontation is deemed to be required with the Anatre Possenti, it is considered advisable to attempt their eliminations in small batches or individuals - this is particularly true of the Pope Salvarentus VI, whose avatar status grants extremely powerful combat potential. Possible avenues for exploration include:

  • Inspiring civil rebellion among the lay class
    • Possible re-emergence of democracy? Of USA?
  • Persuasion of the Warrior Cats to move against the Church
  • Pushing the entirety of the chunk into space

cards.title: La Sur-Arbre Edges, Fangs, and Heels
cards.content:
This page outlines the Edges (Major/Systemic advantages that make planning against La Sur-Arbre difficult), Fangs (specific forces and weapons that they can deploy against us in a pinch), and Heels (weak spots and pressure points we can leverage to take them out) that currently apply to La Sur-Arbre. As the long-term goal of the organisation is to eliminate the Anatre Possenti, the goal of this dossier can be shorthanded to the overthrow or capitulation of La Sur-Arbre; while a solution that does not disadvantage the ordinary citizens of La Sur-Arbre is preferable, bold moves will be required to take down a foe on this scale.

Edges:
  • Location: Due to their control over the entirety of a chunk (though a small one), all operations will need to account for travel to/from the chunk. Ideally, teleportation would be used in place of a spelljammer to maintain secrecy
  • Fortifications: Aside from agricultural spaces, the seat of power is entirely surrounded in high, sturdy walls. If a full-combat scenario is required, these will be difficult to surmount
  • Divine Power: Due to their control of an entire religion, our enemy possesses a great wealth of magical energy in the form of Divine magic. This provides them with access to high-level magical fortifications, and the possibility of excellent remote spycraft via Divination magic
Fangs:
  • Warrior Cats: Highly elite tabaxi warriors who can be deployed by the heads of the church (and, thereby, the Anatre Possenti) at a moment's notice. Extremely fast-moving and lethal at a distance and close range - should not be engaged with unless absolutely necessary.
  • Cassus Belli: They have previously shown a willingness to go to war with New Limnsworth, and have the capacity to drop high-yield explosives from overhead, as well as deploying their considerable military. If we can avoid all-out conflict with this group, it will avoid unnecessary casualties.
    [note: this could equally be turned to an advantage. War could distract the Anatre Possenti from their participation in Big Five activity; consider if war is acceptable to gain advantage]
Heels:
  • USA Loyalists: In our research, we have found a not inconsiderable portion of the population remains loyal to the old nation of USA; fomenting a people's revolt may be possible.
  • Avatar Status: As with all religious institutions, the Anatre Possenti relies on Pope Salvarentus' position as the Avatar of Salvation to retain control of the church. Supplanting the Pope with a new pretender may cause their structures to crumble
  • Warrior Cats: In addition to being one of their Fangs, the Warrior Cats technically owe no allegiance to the Church, and are largely allied due to convenience. Offering this group a better alternative may flip them (this would prove complicated, but could be extremely valuable long-term)

characters.name: Iona
characters.content: Commander of the Grey Wardens. A woman in her late-50s/early-60s, Iona is a kind but stern figure who cares deeply about stopping the impending Blight.

characters.name: Trahan
characters.content: Knight Commander of the Ferelden Templars. A young woman with a fierce hatred of apostates and very strong attachment to Chantry doctrine. Opposes the Wardens for our use of magic and our devotion to what she sees as a lost cause. Full name is L. Lowen Trahan.

characters.name: Dieudonnée
characters.content: Top-tier merchant and information broker travelling with our group as we complete our treaties. She and her brother <character onclick='charDetails(`Rainier`)'>Rainier</character> are originally from Orlais, but fled the country following a falling out with Dieudonnée's former mentor, La Dame, over Rainier's arranged marraige.

characters.name: Rainier
characters.content:
Bodyguard to Dieudonnée travelling with our group as we complete our treaties. He and his sister <character onclick='charDetails(`Dieudonnée`)'>Dieudonnée</character> are originally from Orlais, but fled the country following a falling out with Dieudonnée's former mentor, La Dame, over Rainier's arranged marraige.
Currently in a situationship with Nine (alongside Rowan).

characters.name: Estell Gornemant
characters.content: Bastard son of the late king of Ferelden, King Tristram Gornemant II. Inducted as a Grey Warden before any of the party members, Estell was a former knight in <character onclick='charDetails(`Trahan`)'>Commander Trahan's</character> Templar outfit.

characters.name: Arl Pelham Gornemant
characters.content: Arl of Maroon Hills. Married to the <character onclick='charDetails(`Arlessa Carina`)'>Arlessa Carina</character> and father of <character onclick='charDetails(`Tristam Gornemant III`)'>Tristram Gornemant III</character>, brother of the late king Tristram Gornemant II (and thereby uncle to <character onclick='charDetails(`Estell Gornemant`)'>Estell Gornemant</character>). Currently sick (due to a lingering poison) and bedbound as a result. Brought back from the brink of death by our party, but remains seriously ill. Our treaty with Maroon Hills hinges on curing him of his malaise.

characters.name: Elouan Yannick
characters.content: The leader of the Maroon Hills Knights Corps, a military group widely renowned as the greatest soldiers in the Kingdom of Ferelden.

characters.name: Arlessa Carina
characters.content: Arlessa of Maroon Hills, wife of <character onclick='charDetails(`Arl Pelham Gornemant`)'>Arl Pelham</character>, and mother of <character onclick='charDetails(`Tristram Gornemant III`)'>Tristram Gornemant III</character>. Ill-advisedly leaned on <character onclick='charDetails(`Shou Tucker`)'>Shou Tucker</character> for her son's magical education, letting the snake who poisoned her husband into the house. Slightly wary of the Grey Warden's due to <character onclick='charDetails(`Kim Keeper`)'>Kim's</character> castings, but ultimately relying on us to save her husband.

characters.name: Shou Tucker
characters.content: Former Circle-Tower mage who fled the Tower in unknown circumstances. One of the researchers who made Nina into her current half-abomination form. Former magical tutor to <character onclick='charDetails(`Tristram Gornemant III`)'>Tristram Gornemant III</character>.

characters.name: Tristram Gornemant III
characters.content: Son of <character onclick='charDetails(`Arl Pelham Gornemant`)'>the Arl</character> and <character onclick='charDetails(`Arlessa Carina`)'>Arlessa</character> of Maroon Hills, heir apparent to the Arldom of Maroon Hills, and second in line to the throne of Ferelden. Affectionately nicknamed 'The Boy', our party picked him up in Maroon Hills to provide magical education after his previous mentor, <character onclick='charDetails(`Shou Tucker`)'>Shou Tucker</character>, turned traitor. Travelled with us for a while, but was recently left in the care of Na Dathanna of the Fforest Fawr, who are adequate magical teachers.

characters.name: Androste
characters.content: The messianic Christ-figure of this world and former favourite of the Maker. Died approximately 1,000 years ago, also referred to as the Bride of the Maker. Was burned alive by the Tivinter Imperium for preaching the doctrine of the Maker (advocating for slavery abolition). Sold out to Tivinter by her mortal husband. Born roughly 500 years after the Second Sin, bringing the Maker's attention back to Thedes. Her death led to the Maker's abandonment of the world, according to Chantry canon.

characters.name: Kim Keeper
characters.content: Daughter of Bann Harold and Dorothea Keeper, former heir apparant to the family holdings and title. Rescued by <character onclick='charDetails(`Iona`)'>Iona</character> following the Templars raiding the family's home for her father's supposed crimes (as yet unproven in a court of law). Received a sterling education in magick from her mother, and became a devotee of the Cult of the Wolf Mother in the same stroke. Fiercely devoted to Iona for her rescuing Kim in her hour of direst need. Enthusiastic but slightly unbalanced member of the Grey Wardens.

characters.name: Arvek
characters.content: A Qunari from Par Volen in the north. Due to catastrophic climate damage to the continent, Arvek, his brother Calder, and a group of their community fled in search of safety. They landed in Denim, where they were searched and weapons taken from them, before being sent to live in the Elvish slums. Arvek and Calder’s weapons were both taken by the city. Without his sword, Calder will never be a fully developed and respected member of the community, so Arvek swears to find it and heads out. He meets the party in Nacron, where he was the victim of racism, and the party promise the locals to keep and eye on him.

characters.name: Rowan
characters.content:
Youngest child of the ancient high mage <character onclick='charDetails(`Malgwyn`)'>Malgwyn</character>, a nervous and deeply introverted man. Cut off from most socialisation outside of his mother for the majority of his life, Rowan has only recently ventured into the wider world. Joined up with the party after spying on us via his familiar, Chamomile, for a while. A powerful druid in his own right, but requires lots of reassurance and guidance as he makes his way through the world.
Currently dating Nine.

characters.name: The Church of Ascension
characters.content: The state church of the chunk of <character onclick='charDetails(`La Sur-Arbre`)'>La Sur-Arbre</character>. Headed up by Pope Salvarentus VI, now confirmed to be the head of the Anatre Possenti. The Church maintains a near-monopoly on worship of the god Ress (Domains: Salvation and Uplifting), and through this worship commands the avatarship of this god.

characters.name: La Sur-Arbre
characters.content: A chunk floating in a static orbit around the Limnian chunk. Hosts <character onclick='charDetails(`The Church of Ascension`)'>The Church of Ascension</character>. Formerly the capital city of the United Settlements of Aarakocra, renamed to La Sur-Arbre following the popular uprising of the citizenry against the democratic republic of the country, as backed by the Church.
